subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Review charts for Shavian Quikscript Extensions
msgSnippet: I am sorry to be coming back to this all so late, but happy to see that the proposal is moving forward. With regards to letter names, I think that sticking
messageBody:
I am sorry to be coming back to this all so late, but happy to see that the proposal is moving forward.

With regards to letter names, I think that sticking with the originals in the manual is good (even if the names are not themselves ideal).  However, in the proposal.txt file I note that letter J'AI is spelled with an apostrophe, and I believe it needs to be a hyphen (J-AI).  That probably needs to be cleared up if this is not a shared code point (see my point below).

I also found Michael's first-page table to be a bit confusing, but it seems to me that it simply illustrates the commonality between the two scripts.  The table on the second page lists only the quickscript letters which are not common.  This would be the chart that is submitted with the proposal, I believe.  I agree that utter should be shared with ado despite the confusion of Shavian also having up, two symbols for essentially the same sound.

It seems to me there might be two extra candidates for merging: pea and j'ai.  While these certainly look a bit different between Shavian and QuickScript, they are almost as similar as the foot and ooze characters are to their Shavian counterparts, and could possibly be seen as slight variations on the same glyph.  Certainly, there is chance for confusion between, say, QuickScript thaw and Shavian peep, but given the other cases where the same glyph is used for totally different sounds I think that is only a minor issue.  I think these glyphs are 'close enough' in shape while having the same sound.

oliver

On Wed 2007.10.31, at 15:28, amd64_hacker wrote:

I'm a little confused by page 1.
I see two tables which seem to show the same space but have different
values, is that a typo?

I omitted characters with alternate forms (DAY, UTTER and similar) from
the draft.
I thought they needed extra scrutiny since they don't always behaved in
the same way as their Shavian counterparts.
For example, UTTER's alternate form looks something like a reverse ROE
or a Shavian LOLL, I think that makes it unsuitable for merging.
DAY/DEAD, I'm fairly certain, has the same alternate form in Shavian and
QuikScript.

The glyphs for AH, AWE and MIME, NUN are identical, but the sounds are
not alike.

Other than those minor points, I think that is what we want.

What happens script wise if we merge Shavian and QuikScript?
I presume a new Unicode block will be created for the 'QuikScript
Extentions', but do we inherit the script code Shaw or do we get a new one?

Michael Everson wrote:
>
> Please review the charts I made to see if (at least) I understood the
> unification model.
>
> The letters AH and AWE are very very similar to Shavian MIME and NUN.
> Very similar.
>
> Michael
>
>

I am sorry to be coming back to this all so late, but happy to see  
that the proposal is moving forward.

With regards to letter names, I think that sticking with the  
originals in the manual is good (even if the names are not themselves  
ideal).  However, in the proposal.txt file I note that letter J'AI is  
spelled with an apostrophe, and I believe it needs to be a hyphen (J- 
AI).  That probably needs to be cleared up if this is not a shared  
code point (see my point below).

I also found Michael's first-page table to be a bit confusing, but it  
seems to me that it simply illustrates the commonality between the  
two scripts.  The table on the second page lists only the quickscript  
letters which are not common.  This would be the chart that is  
submitted with the proposal, I believe.  I agree that utter should be  
shared with ado despite the confusion of Shavian also having up, two  
symbols for essentially the same sound.

It seems to me there might be two extra candidates for merging: pea  
and j'ai.  While these certainly look a bit different between Shavian  
and QuickScript, they are almost as similar as the foot and ooze  
characters are to their Shavian counterparts, and could possibly be  
seen as slight variations on the same glyph.  Certainly, there is  
chance for confusion between, say, QuickScript thaw and Shavian peep,  
but given the other cases where the same glyph is used for totally  
different sounds I think that is only a minor issue.  I think these  
glyphs are 'close enough' in shape while having the same sound.

oliver
